title: Phil Spencer set to name Britain's beach hut of the year
text:
289 shares
View
comments
They’ve become a symbol of the British seaside, and these brightly painted and cosy beach huts are in the running to be named the best of them all.
From Brighton and Bournemouth to Minster and Milford, the huts vying for the Beach Hut of the Year award offer spectacular views of the sea and special memories for their owners.
Some are named for late relatives and one is designed specifically for cancer patients, while others have played host to family gatherings, celebrities and even wedding receptions.
‘Betty’, at Victoria Esplanade, Mersea Island, has a shabby-chic interior with items sourced from charity shops
This Cath Kidston-styled hut is one of two that make up ‘Millie’s Beach Huts at Southcliff Parade, Essex
Near Hordle Cliff, Milford-on-Sea, ‘Hut 295’ is a sanctuary for families with children suffering from cancer
Above all else, these huts provide a tranquil place for holidaymakers to get away from it all and soak up the sun.
The nationwide search to find Britain’s best beach hut was launched by Towergate Insurance, with the final shortlist being whittled down to 11 after hundreds of entries were sent in from around the UK.

Two holidaymakers win five-figure payout from Thomas Cook... 289 shares Located at Southcliff Parade, Walton-on-the-Naze, in Essex, The Daisy Hut is named in memory of owner Anna Brooks’ daughter, Daisy, who died from brain cancer on her seventh birthday.
With a golden sandy beach and nearby pier, the hut is brand new but built in traditional style complete with a porthole and decking.
Set on the coast at West Prom in Essex, ‘Underwood’ has been in Marion Witton’s family for almost 100 years
‘Beach Hut 2’ was built as part of a pilot project at The Leas, Minster-on-Sea in Kent
SHORTLIST FOR BRITAIN'S BEST BEACH HUT
‘Indian Summer’ – Southcliff Parade, Walton-on-the-Naze
‘Beach Hut 2’, The Leas, Minster-on-Sea, Sheerness, Kent
‘Hut 19a’, Hove Seafront, East Sussex
‘Hut 289’, Hordle Cliff, Milford on Sea, Hampshire
'Millie’s Beach Huts’, Southcliff Parade, Walton-on-the-Naze
‘Hut 295’, Hordle Cliffs, Milford-on-Sea
'The Little Beach Hut of Dreams’, King’s Esplanade, Hove
‘Underwood’, West Prom, Brightlingsea, Colchester, Essex
‘The Daisy Hut’, Southcliff Parade, Walton on the Naze, Essex
‘Salty Paws’, East Beach, Sheringham, North Norfolk
‘Betty’, Victoria Esplanade, Mersea Island
* Winner to be announced on 7 August
Another entry, called Underwood, has been in owner Marion Witton’s family for almost 100 years, although it had to be rebuilt in 2013.
The hut, at West Prom in Colchester, Essex, was washed away by floods, but the family pulled together and spent many weekends painting a brand new one with pink and white stripes.
The winner and runners-up will be decided by a panel of judges, including Channel 4 presenter Phil Spencer, but the public can go online and vote for their favourite.
‘The Little Beach Hut of Dreams’ is a cosy spot with uninterrupted views at King’s Esplanade, Hove
With a Buddha theme, ‘Indian Summer’ offers relaxation for visitors to Southcliff, Walton-on-the-Naze
At Hove Seafront in East Sussex, ‘Hut 19a’ works with MacMillan Charity and offers patients some TLC along with tea and cake (pictured: retired tennis player and former UK No 1 Greg Rusedski)
When the winner is announced on 7 August, he or she will receive £1,000 for their beach hut association, free beach hut insurance for a year and a certificate for the wall.
Emma Watson of Towergate Leisure Division said: ‘The quality of some of the huts that entered this year’s competition has been outstanding.
‘There is clearly a huge amount of passion for beach huts in the UK and people spend a great deal of time and money into making them a home away from home.
Beach huts in prime locations can cost tens of thousands of pounds, with one at Mudeford near Christchurch, Dorset, selling for £180,000 in 2013.
Smaller and less extravagant huts in less desired locations can sell for as little as £6,000.
'The Daisy Hut' (left) at Southcliff Parade, Walton-on-the-Naze; ‘Hut 289’ (right) at Milford on Sea, Hampshire
‘Salty Paws’, at East Beach in North Norfolk, was rebuilt after a previous hut was destroyed by a storm
